root.title: Web Rendering Models
root.content:
Server-Side vs. Client-Side

This module explores the two primary models for rendering web applications. The choice between them has significant impacts on performance, user experience, and SEO.

quiz.question: Which rendering model generally provides better SEO out-of-the-box?

ssr.title: Server-Side Rendering (SSR)
ssr.content:
Server-Side Rendering (SSR)

In SSR, the server generates the full HTML for a page in response to a browser request. The browser can then display this content immediately.

  • Pros: Excellent for SEO as search engine crawlers can easily read the content. Faster initial page load (First Contentful Paint).
  • Cons: Can be slower for subsequent navigations as each page requires a full round-trip to the server. Higher server load.
  • Example: Traditional web applications, Blazor Server.

csr.title: Client-Side Rendering (CSR)
csr.content:
Client-Side Rendering (CSR)

In CSR, the server sends a minimal HTML shell and a large JavaScript bundle. The browser then executes the JavaScript to fetch data and render the page content.

  • Pros: Rich, interactive 'app-like' experiences. Faster navigation after the initial load as only data needs to be fetched, not full HTML pages.
  • Cons: Slower initial load time (Time to Interactive). Can be challenging for SEO as crawlers may not execute the JavaScript correctly.
  • Example: Single-Page Applications (SPAs) like React, Angular, Vue, and Blazor WebAssembly.
